Underground nuclear detonations do not always " throw dirt and rocks up into the air to form craters.." .
Depending on if a detonation is deep enough some craters are formed by the surface collapsing into an underground cavity created by heating the underground bedrock to tens of millions of degrees until it's atoms reach a plasma state of electrons and protons separated and cannot cool back down into rocks again . This plasma seeps out of the ground and leaves a spherical hole that eventually cools and collapses in .
Extensive seeping of plasma or venting of plasma into the atmosphere from nuclear excavating of underground bases and storage facilities can cause a visible corona effect in the sky around the sun and particle radiation can reach pandemic proportions

This is super cool! It hadn't occurred to me that an underground nuclear explosion would be the closest analog to a meteor impact, but now that you've explained it... it feels like I've always known that, haha! I found this video additionally fascinating because I live near another important Apollo training site: the shield volcanoes of Hawai‘i's Big Island! This was another place the astronauts were trained in geology, and lunar buggies were tested. Again, similar terrain to the moon, but also the rocks from shield volcanoes like those in Hawai‘i are geochemically very similar to Lunar and Martian regolith! There's a long (and continuing) history of cutting-edge space science that goes on here for that reason!

I have Trinitite, from the 1st nuclear detonation, codenamed "Trinity". It's nuclear "melt glass" formed from sand in the Alamogordo Desert. It is still radioactive, too. Under my microscope, it looks very interesting! It has many gas bubbles, frozen in time since July 16th, 1945. Many of them are only few microns in diameter. It does look similar to some of the samples brought back from The Moon under a microscope. A lot of what was brought back is called KREEP (Potassium Rare Earth Elements & Phosphorus). Also, the cosmic radiation is much higher on The Moon, since it has almost no atmosphere and magnetic field. And any lunar (terrestrial) radiation can travel much further as well, again because of the sparse atmosphere. So, testing in these radioactive craters on Earth is a good idea if you're going to The Moon and you want to be prepared!

1. the astronauts were not merely "expert pilots." They were, in fact, all professional scientists and engineers and they contributed a lot to science, besides being astronauts. i asked this in a video that you posted 2 years ago, but regarding the double slit experiments and the quantum eraser experiment, is it possible that as particles travel and their properties oscillate, like how a photon is an electromagnetic wave that has a frequency, that they release an immediately undetectable amount of energy in the form of virtual particles? i say "immediately undetectable" because over relatively short distances it wouldnt be noticeable, like the light from our sun or the other stars in our galaxy, but if you could collect these virtual particles before they annihilate each other, and keep them from annihilating each other,  over a looooooong time you would see a detectible amount of energy. how does this deal with the double slit experiments? well, if it does give off virtual particles as its frequency peaks with each oscillation, then that virtual wave could go through the opposite slit and interfere with the particles trajectory on the other side. well how does this fit in with the part where the photon will produce 2 lines if we detect which slit it went through? well that has to do more with how we detect the photon, they are electromagnetic waves, so the only way we can detect which slit they went through is with a very sensitive electromagnetic detector, which gives off a very small magnetic field, this magnetic field is kind of a barrier for virtual particles, so the wave doesnt get through and thus doesnt interfere with the photons trajectory. i know this is all postulation, but you gotta ask before you can find out, right? also, its possible that once you turn a photon into 2 entangled photons, that one photon gives off "regular" virtual particles and the other gives off "anti" virtual particles, which would conserve energy, and make the entanglement mystery a little less of a mystery. if entangled particles give off opposite virtual particles, then this could be the link that connects them. energy needs to be conserved so as you distance these 2 entangled particles for one another their virtual particles need to annihilate, so instead of being a wave that propagates out in every direction, the virtual particles are pulled to their opposites and annihilate in the middle, pretty  much instantaneously no matter how far apart the entangled particles are. these are virtual particles we're talking about, so they very well can teleport through space if their opposite is too far away. again just postulation, id love to hear your opinion.

Most of the craters on the lunar surface have shallow, flat floors with modest slopes. This is in contrast to the deep pit and steep angle of the nuclear test crater. Meteor crater also has a flat floor and modest slope angle. When observing the moon one should also consider the peculiar  craters; those that have craters perched preferentially on the rim of another crater, straight edge craters that form polygonal shapes such as a hexagon, and raised mounds/clumps/rocks at the center if  flat craters. These features are reproduceable using electrical discharge machining in low pressure silica. Electrical currents can also produce intense heat and thunderstorms can produce gamma rays, so its not unlikely that a large current could heat the moon and form the crystalline rock and shocked quarts. Well reducing radiation levels is a bit subjective.  Yes within an hour the levels at the lip of the crater were instantly fatal, but within 6 months you could safely walk across the bottom of the crater and within about 1.5 years it was as low as working in a nuclear power plant (which you can only do for 5 years usually).  Understand that explosions underground and under water are less efficient explosions leaving behind extra radiation so radiation levels from most nuclear bomb detonated in the atmosphere have considerably less radiation.  Of course the US and Russia did have bombs that could be set to a lower yield that would produce much more radiation.  The scariest tests though in my opinion were the upper atmosphere tests in the van alden belt.

NB: Dark regions are not randomly called 'mare', asthe video might make you feel. It means 'sea', as it geographically reminds us of our seas. The closer, our, side of the moon is full of them and has less craters, not because it's younger, but because it's harder for meteors to hit our 'inner' side of the moon.

On google maps you can open satellite images and then choose moon (as well as other planets, it's really cool💜). Check out the outer side, it's been severely molested by meteorites to a an almost disturbing sight:)
Furthermore, if you know where to look and zoom in, you can find satellite images of various lunar landings.

Calling the Sedan test an "underground" test is a sophistry.  It was, more accurately, a cratering test, a test which was designed to explode into the atmosphere; underground tests are at least 2400 feet underground.  The US did Sedan in July of 1962 and the last above-ground test in October, and the Soviets did a very similar test to Sedan that built Lake Chagan in January 1965, and was internationally criticized for it, as the PTBT banned all but underground testing in 1963.  The USSR interpreted the ban not to affect industrial-use tests, and did a dozen or so in the next five years, though none as big as Sedan.
Just to add some info. As mentioned by Destin from Smarter Everyday, lunar sample were brought back in vacuum and later in pure nitrogen atmosphere as to retain its originality

Selection criteria for applicants for each group of astronauts were;
Group 2:
were experienced test pilots, with 1,500 hours test pilot flying time, who had graduated from a military test pilot school, or had test pilot experience with NASA or the aircraft industry;
had flown high-performance jet aircraft;
had earned a degree in engineering or the physical or biological sciences;
were a U.S. citizen, under 35 years of age, and 6 feet 0 inches (1.83 m) or less in height; and
recommended by employer.
Group 3:
U.S. citizens;
aged less than 34 on June 30, 1963;
6 feet 0 inches (1.83 m) or less in height;
with a degree in engineering or the physical sciences;
were experienced test pilots, or with 1,000 hours jet pilot flying time; and
recommended by employer.
Group 4:
Be a United States citizen;
Born on or after August 1, 1930;
6 feet 0 inches (1.83 m) or less in height;
With a doctorate in the natural sciences, medicine or engineering, or the equivalent.
Group 5:
Be a United States citizen;
Born on or after December 1, 1929;
6 feet 0 inches (1.83 m) or less in height;
With a bachelor's degree in the physical or biological sciences, or engineering; and
Either a graduate of an armed force test pilot school or with 1,000 hours of jet flying experience.
(source: Wikipedia pages)

2 Misconceptions:
5:45 - Most impacts do create circular craters, but it is possible for an impact to create a oblong crater. It has to hit at an extremely shallow angle, and begin to 'skip' off the surface. An example is Messier crater on the moon!
8:53 - Lunar samples were transported back in a triple-sealed case (the ALSRC) that was closed OUTSIDE the space craft, meaning the lunar rocks were in a Lunar-like atmosphere until they got back to earth and their case was opened by NASA.

Here in NW New Mexico we have a Plowshare site called Gasbuggy. I've visited it. It was an underground test conducted over 4,000' down so other than Prairie Dogs and a plaque there wasn't much to see. They were testing nuclear fracturing for enhanced oil and gas recovery. It worked but the contamination and PR that would have been required to sell gas to consumers killed the idea. BTW - the gas radioactivity was less than 10% of normal background. They set off two more sites, one with two bombs, each in different zones, in NW Colorado and 2 more a little east of Carlsbad, NM

8:54 onwards: I thought Destin and Brady (Smarter Every Day and Objectivity respectively) said the moon rock samples were collected under vacuum (moon having no atmosphere) and brought back to Earth in specially designed and made vacuum boxes. I recall one of them saying that the moon dust on the astronauts' suits DID react with the oxygen in the module, as they could smell it, but nothing catastrophic or even detrimental to the astronauts happened. 9:18 - the samples were never exposed to oxygen. The concern was if it was accidentally exposed to oxygen AND as a result caught fire. They went from vacuum on the surface to hermetically-sealed bags to a vacuum and later nitrogen environment on Earth. Being that the surface of the moon is basically a vacuum, it made it easy to just vacuum-pack the samples in-situ. The worst thing other than a fire would be contaminating the samples and causing them to react. That would render surface sampling useless in determining anything chemical about the moon.
